1.text: Senseless Galatians! Christ was openly presented before your eyes as crucified—who then bewitched you not to obey the truth?

2.text: I just want to hear this from you: did you receive the Spirit by the works of the law or by believing what you heard?

3.text: Are you that senseless that having begun in the Spirit, you now end in the flesh?

4.text: Did you suffer so many things in vain, if it is indeed in vain?

5.text: He who provides you with the Spirit and works miracles among you, does he do it by the works of the law or by the hearing of faith?

6.text: Even as Abraham “believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousness,”

7.text: know, therefore, that those who are of faith are likewise Abraham’s children.

8.text: And foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, the Scripture announced the future Good News to Abraham by saying, “In you all the nations will be blessed.”

9.text: And so, those of faith are blessed with the faithful Abraham.

10.text: But those who depend on the works of the law are under a curse, for it is written:  Cursed is everyone who does not persevere   in all the things that are written in the book of the law,   to do them.

11.text: Now it is obvious that no one is justified by the law before God, for “The righteous will live by faith.”

12.text: The law is not of faith, but, “The one who does these things will live by them.”

13.text: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for our sake. For it is written, “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree,”

14.text: so that Abraham’s blessing might also come to the Gentiles through Christ Jesus, and that we might {all} receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.

15.text: Brethren, speaking of a human example: even a human contract, once it has been confirmed, cannot be cancelled or altered.

16.text: Now the promises were spoken to Abraham and to his seed. [Notice that] he does not say, “to seeds,” as if there were many, but as of one, “to your seed,” which is Christ.

17.text: What I am saying is this: the law, which came four hundred thirty years after the covenant previously confirmed by God in Christ, does not cancel it to make the promise of no effect.

18.text: If the inheritance comes from the law, it is no longer from the promise; but in fact, God granted it to Abraham by way of a promise.

19.text: What then is the law about? It was added because of transgressions, until the seed to whom the promise had been made should come, and it was established through the angels, by the hand of a mediator.

20.text: Now there is no mediator when there is only one party, and God is one.

21.text: Therefore, is the law against God’s [own] promises? Certainly not! If a law had been given which could make alive, then certainly, righteousness would have been from the law.

22.text: But in fact, the Scriptures declared all things to be captive under sin, so that the promise might be given to those who believe—that is, by faith in Jesus Christ.

23.text: Nevertheless, before faith came, we were kept in custody under the law, locked up to wait for the faith which would later be revealed.

24.text: Hence, the law was our tutor which was to bring us to Christ, so that we might be justified by faith.

25.text: But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor,

26.text: and you are all God’s children, through faith in Christ Jesus!

27.text: For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ.

28.text: There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus.

29.text: If you are Christ’s, then you are Abraham’s seed and heirs according to the promise.
